short_description: Mexican authorities declared the Colorado River Delta area a reserve for regional fishing species.
Gillnets for totoaba fishing are prohibited.
IUCN listed the totoaba as an endangered species.
The Glen Canyon Dam is filled, further reducing river flow.
Trawl shrimp fleet in the AGC significantly increases due to the National Fisheries Development Plan.
All islands in the Gulf of California are granted federal protected status.
Secretariat of Fisheries issued a total experimental ban on private capture permits, giving exclusivity to fishing cooperatives.
Franchises are granted during the ban period to control illegal capture.
Campamento Tortuguero El Verde incorporated into INP's Turtle Program and decreed Natural Protected Area.
Research and rehabilitation tanks constructed at the CRIP-Bahía de Los Ángeles station.
The IUCN listed the vaquita as vulnerable on the Red List of Threatened Species.
The Infectious Hypodermal and Hematopoietic Necrosis Virus (IHHNV) is first introduced to Mexico through white shrimp postlarvae from the US for cultivation purposes.
River flow restrictions to the Colorado River delta begin.
All shrimp farms and laboratories on the Sonora coast are infected with IHHNV; lowest shrimp capture in AGC fishery history recorded with drastic decrease in primary organic productivity.
The Sian Ka’an Biosphere Reserve is declared a World Heritage Site.
Number of overexploited wells in Baja California Sur increases from 3 to over 580, with 78% showing increased salinity.
Cabo Pulmo National Park (CPNP) emerges from a bottom-up initiative by local fishermen and academics due to coral reef degradation.
Restructuring of federal ministries occurs, leading to the decline of the fishing sector.
Federal executive declares a total ban on all marine turtle species in Mexican waters.
Public resources used to build infrastructure for fishing cooperatives on Pacific coast for high-value products.
First generation of funders, including Packard and Sandler Foundations, begin marine conservation efforts in the region.
Gillnets prohibited for totoaba fishing in established area.
UN Conference on Environment & Development in Rio leads to policy changes.
IUCN changes vaquita status to endangered.
Upper Gulf of California & Colorado River Delta Biosphere Reserve created.
Mexican government lists vaquita as protected species.
Mexican Fund for Conservation of Nature (FMCN) created.
Alto Golfo Reserve Management Program implemented.
Cabo Pulmo National Park (CPNP) created.
Golfo de Santa Clara field station operations begin.
National Council of Natural Protected Areas created.
NOM-002-PESC-1996 mandates TEDs in shrimp trawling.
Kyoto Protocol signed to reduce GHG emissions.
Fund for Natural Protected Areas (FANP) established.
El Niño event increases shrimp catches.
US mortgage credit expansion impacts Baja California capital.
Mexico financial deregulation extends mortgage credit.
FAO sponsors workshops on shrimp bycatch solutions.
CONANP established as decentralized SEMARNAT body.
Spectra fishing net material begins use.
Vaquita population decline becomes exponential due to gillnets.
SEMARNAT begins overseeing environmental zoning & LGEEPA regulation published.
CICIMAR study for Espiritu Santo MPA public consultation.
Los Cabos launches Marine Turtle Monitoring Program.
Mexico primary sector subsidies disappear, shifts to transfers.
Development boom begins in Cabo and La Paz region.
Balandra conflict takes place.
FAO releases Reykjavik Declaration on responsible fisheries.
Coastal oases in Baja California Sur urbanize and develop agroindustry.
Smaller oases in Baja California Sur disappear due to abandonment or water diversion.
World Summit on Sustainable Development promotes ecosystem-based fisheries management.
NRC holds workshop on fishing effects on ecosystems.
CTDMO launches environmental culture and science dissemination program.
Escalera Nautica project initiated.
Al Costa alliance formed to monitor Escalera Nautica project.
SEMARNAT launches program to analyze oasis ecosystems in PBC.
INAPESCA and WWF develop suripera net to replace gillnets.
Gulf of California declared UNESCO Natural World Heritage Site.
Escalera Nautica project receives funding and begins implementation.
Watton family discovers and expresses desire to protect Gulf of California.
Eastern Gulf of California records maximum historical sardine catch.
Mexican Constitution reforms to establish SNIEG.
Gulf of California Marine Ecological Zoning Program decreed and implemented.
Water extraction in Baja California Sur programmed for reduction.
Low adoption of localized irrigation in Santo Domingo Valley, BCS.
RIDISOS network formed to investigate Sudcalifornian oases.
Escalera Nautica project (mega-project) emerges under Vicente Fox's government.
PROFEPA accredits RHPTM as Mexico's largest participatory surveillance committee.
Watton Family Foundation begins environmental work in Gulf of California.
Global economic crisis begins (US & Europe).
CIMARES created for sustainable management of Mexico's seas and coasts.
New park authority established for Cabo Pulmo National Park (CPNP).
Global financial crisis causes Escalera Nautica project to disappear.
WWF-Carlos Slim Foundation Alliance established to conserve Mexico's natural heritage.
COBI begins marine sensor network in reserves after hypoxia event.
WWF-FCS & Pronatura Mexico implement strategy for Vaquita-Friendly fish products.
OECD Better Life Index created to measure well-being.
Satellite tracking (VMS) system introduced for industrial fishing vessels.
Watton Family Foundation begins initial grant-making portfolio in Mexico.
Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) transitions out of shrimp fisheries work in Sinaloa.
Land tenure conflicts escalate in Los Comondú due to ejido boundaries and drought.
Commercial agriculture declines and biocultural knowledge lost in Los Comondú.
Census data shows population for Cabo Pulmo, Loreto, La Paz; BCS has low density, high migration.
Watton Family Foundation promotes market leverage for sustainable seafood.
Watton Family Foundation supports Smartfish's 'Value Rescue Model'.
Watton Family Foundation invests in capacity building for fishing communities.
Totoaba fishing exploded
Mexican government Totoaba strategy
Illegal totoaba trade national security
US-Mexico vaquita cooperation
Ghost Net Removal Program launched
Trilateral totoaba meeting
Gulf CA UNESCO World Heritage in Danger
Illegal fishing conflicts & net theft
Yucatan trophic level decrease
Eastern Gulf CA fisheries status
Shrimp trawl impact book & MPAs set
UN Ocean Science Decade proclaimed
HLP Ocean Economy formed
PROBLUE program launched
Clean Oceans Initiative launched
Hurricane Odile strikes BCS
ASA BCS established & dormant
COVID-19 migration wave BC
Migration routes shift, crime follows
Water availability challenges BC
EDF brought in, fisheries dialogue
Impacto Colectivo platform created
Org crime in Totoaba fishery peaks
Mex gov't direct fisheries subsidies
COVID-19 market shifts for fishermen
SAGARPA Gulf curvina RBM
Pacific Lobster MSC certified
Senator introduces catch limit law
Paredones Amarillos mining conflict
CONANP NW Mexico ANP evaluation
Gulf CA Biodiversity Action Plan
PANGAS project Northern GOC
ALCOSTA alliance operates
Comprehensive Strategies Stage
BioMar program operates
Programa Pescadero operates
Gov't Temporary Employment Program (PET)
Todos Santos real estate conflict
Tres Santos Punta Lobos disruption
GTC shark ban crisis
ASA project starts
Hurricane Odile vulnerability revealed
